I've also moved all java under `3rdparty/java` and moved python semver library under `3rdparty/python`.

title: Make sure permissions are set before writing artifacts
body:
Bazel defaults all packages to 0555 permissions which means they are
readable and executable but not writable. If you run the compile script
twice in a row or any of the artifacts already exist in the destination
folder the copy will fail because no one has write privileges. This
change makes sure that if the file exists it has sufficient permissions
to allow for the script to overwrite it.

This fixes: https://github.com/twitter/heron/issues/288

title: Add Scheduler implementation for REEF on YARN cluster

- Add conf files for reef cluster. Update BUILD scripts to copy config files
  during client install.
- Add ILauncher implementation for REEF cluster
- Add ISchduler implementation for REEF
- Add Driver (master/AM) implementation which will invoke Heron scheduler
- Add lib dependencies for REEF cluster
- Add REEF configuration options needed to start Heron Components
- Add REEF task to launch Heron Executor and TMaster and Executor subsequently.
- Add the configuration options needed by the Task to start the executors.

title: Add a config file for tracker, which can be used to format viz url.
body:
This changes the meaning of `--config-file` in Tracker. It used to mean state manager config file, but now it would mean a generic Tracker config file. The `statemgr-config-file` is now a part of this `heron_tracker.yaml`.

Now, the viz URL is formed based on the format provided in the conf file. The parameters being used are from the execution state.

title: Add code style checks to heron to fix #348
body:
This is disabled by default but can be enabled by adding the `--experimental_action_listener=tools/java:compile_java` flag to a bazel command:

```
$ bazel build --config=darwin heron/spi/src/java:heron-spi \
  --experimental_action_listener=tools/java:compile_java
```

We can turn this flag on by default in `tools/bazel.rc` once we're ready. Also I starteb putting artifacts into `WORKSPACE`. In a separate RB we can remove all jars from `3rdparty` in lieu of this approach.

Please advise if there's a more suitable home for this code.

repo.name: incubator-heron
repo.description: Apache Heron (Incubating) is a realtime, distributed, fault-tolerant stream processing engine from Twitter

title: Refactor scheduler abstraction and fix corresponding implementations
body:
1. Add SchedulerClient interface. Implementing this interface allows an object to manage topology via scheduler.
2. Add two implementations for SchedulerClient interface:
   - SchedulerAsHttpServiceClient, managing topology by sending request to appropriate HTTP endpoint of the topology scheduler service.
   - SchedulerAsLibraryClient, managing topology by invoking IScheduler's interface directly as a library.
3. Remove the interface IRuntimeManager and related stuff (for instance, config), since it is not needed. Put all non-dummy scheduling logic in IScheduler implementation.
4. Add a config to choose different SchedulerClient implementations: scheduler.is.service. By default it is true, meaning that
   there is a daemon processing running IScheduler as a service, receiving requests, scheduling and sending back response.
5. Add AuroraScheduler class, doing the non-dummy scheduling work; no need to put aurora scheduling in prepareXXX() or postXXX(), which violates the aim of prepareXXX() or postXXX(). In Aurora case, scheduler.is.service is set to be false.
   So all scheduling methods in IScheduler will be invoked directly as a library.
6. Separate out scheduling related runtime command, i.e. kill and restart and commands non-related to scheduling, i.e. activate and deactivate.
   They will use different routine.
7. Remove all prepareXXX() and postXXX() in ILauncher and other interfaces, since they are duplicated with initialize() and close(). They can increase the intermediate states during
   scheduling: hard to reason and maintain.
8. Update corresponding implementations, including config files.

Integrated tests with LocalScheduler and AuroraScheduler with following execution sequences:
submit -> submit again -> activate -> deactivate -> deactivate again -> restart -> activate -> kill -> kill again.
Both working fine as expected results.

title: Make Linkchecker (Make Site) automated with formatted errors
body:
#349 @billonahill @kramasamy modified MakeFile to automate make linkchecker (and make site):

If errors, new file "linkchecker-errors.csv" is created with formatted error output, error message displayed to check error file.

If no errors (warnings suppressed), PASS message displayed and "linkchecker-errors.csv" is removed.

This uses a simple line count to test for errors.  Greater than 1 (header) indicates errors exist.  We may want to break out bash logic to separate file, but included in MakeFile for now, just lmk.
As discussed, README does not address separate "make publish" automation.

title: make the config-path option consistent with the default conf
body:
With this change, user provided config-path path should point to a directory that in turn consists of a directory with the name of cluster - similarly to the defaults provided - for example, the following config-path contains two directories one with cluster aurora and the other local

```
 config
  aurora
   README
   client.yaml
   heron.aurora
   heron_internals.yaml
   metrics_sinks.yaml
   packing.yaml
   scheduler.yaml
   statemgr.yaml
   uploader.yaml
  local
   client.yaml
   heron_internals.yaml
   metrics_sinks.yaml
   packing.yaml
   scheduler.yaml
   statemgr.yaml
   uploader.yaml
```

Then the submit will look like 

```
heron submit --config-path config local ~/.heron/examples/heron-examples.jar com.twitter.examples.heron.AckingTopology AckingTopology
```

title: SchedulerMain: make static methods non-static
body:
SchedulerMain: make static methods non-static

```
  - In the library model, SchedulerMain should be instantiated and
    the non-static methods should be called. Doesn't make sense to
    make the methods of SchedulerMain static.
  - In the process model, main method will take care of lauching the
    scheduler.
```

title: View logfiles through proxy instead of redirecting
body:
The hosts where heron-shell is running may not be accessible through the local browser. So when the UI redirects to the logfile, user might see a not-authorized, or simply not-found error.

This change makes Tracker as a proxy for the log file data, and users will remain on the heron-ui domain.

title: Fix concurrent bug in Scheduler abstraction
body:
Heron checks whether topology def exists in StateManager to determine whether a topology already exists; we can consider the topology def in StateManager as a lock preventing any concurrent modifications at the same time.

So it is needed to write topology def to StateManager first when submitting a topology,
and delete topology def at the end when killing a topology.
It is similar when concurrent programming, we need to acquire the lock before any modifications and release the lock at the end after all modifications.

title: Fixes #36 - Adding version checks to bazel_configure.py
body:
This deals with issue #36. A few things to note:
- I wasn't sure where the best place would be to commit the semver python library. Please advise.
- I've done version checking for all things that seem to be consist to handle between OS's, but determining the version of things like gcc and g++ across OS's is difficult. Do we have ubuntu and centos5 hosts that we test with?
- The documentation says 'gcc/g++ >= 4.8.2 (Linux platforms)'. What's the minimum on darwin and is it different? I have 4.2.1 and that compiles.

Here's what the output looks like. I include the found version numbers in parens for the versions we check.

```
$ CMAKE=/Applications/CMake.app/Contents/bin/cmake PYTHON2=/usr/bin/python2.7 ./bazel_configure.py
Using C compiler          : /usr/bin/gcc
Using C++ compiler        : /usr/bin/g++
Using C preprocessor      : /usr/bin/cpp
Using C++ preprocessor    : /usr/bin/cpp
Using linker              : /usr/bin/ld
Using Automake            : /opt/twitter_mde/homebrew/Cellar/automake/1.15/bin/automake (1.15)
Using Autoconf            : /opt/twitter_mde/homebrew/Cellar/autoconf/2.69/bin/autoconf (2.69)
Using Make                : /usr/bin/make (3.81)
Using CMake               : /Applications/CMake.app/Contents/bin/cmake (3.5.1)
Using Python2             : /System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/bin/python2.7 (2.7.10)
Using archiver            : /usr/bin/libtool
Using coverage tool       : /usr/bin/gcov
dwp                       :  not found, but ok
Using nm                  : "/usr/bin/nm"
objcopy                   :  not found, but ok
objdump                   :  not found, but ok
Using strip               : "/usr/bin/strip"
Wrote the environment exec file:    "scripts/compile/env_exec.sh"
```

What's odd though is that when running the above, the `scripts/compile/env_exec.sh` doesn't include any state about python or any other items, just what's below. Is that expected?

```
#!/bin/bash

set -eu

export PATH=/Applications/CMake.app/Contents/bin:$PATH
# Execute the input programs
$*
```

repo.name: incubator-heron
repo.description: Apache Heron (Incubating) is a realtime, distributed, fault-tolerant stream processing engine from Twitter

title: Set ExecutionState completely in LauncherRunner
body:
Currently ILauncher implementation is expected to update details in ExecutionState, which may not be so intuitive (see LocalLauncher.updateExecutionState).heron-tracker ignores any topologies available in state manager if the cluster and role info is not provided by ILaucher implementation.

LaunchRunner has complete information, including cluster and others, and it can be set it at creation time. It reduces the complexity to implement ILauncher.
